page.title: 11FARMING CHANGES SINCE 1930'S
page.content: on marginal farms,near Hownam, in the Scottish Borders,government grants and medical research have led to improved methods and more stock.Sale animals, required to be lean,so continental sires imported to cross with native breeds.Winter feeding has improved,hay turnips and cereal for sheep;hay and silage,sometimes from sealed plastic sacks,for cattle.Calves get extra in a creep.Machines have taken the heavy work out of farming.Hay and straw are formed into bales of various shape,the rolled ones lying outside till needed. No thatched stacks are seen now, the combine harvests in one operaion.Grain is bought in on marginal farms, from those in a more fertile area. Once,a sack tied with string kept the worker dry,with tackety boots on his feet.Now he has a comfortable light suit of plastic,including boots and gloves.
